dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, I was looking at this article, and the title really grabbed me: "Foot Bones Printing."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, I was looking at this article, and the title really grabbed me: Foot Bones Printing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Foot bones printing? What even is that? Like, is someone actually printing... feet?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Foot bones printing? What even is that? Like, is someone actually printing... feet?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, no, no, it's actually about 3D printing, but, um, the way they phrased it, it just, it got my attention, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, no, no, it's actually about three D printing, but, um, the way they phrased it, it just, it got my attention, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, 3D printing. Got it. So what's the big deal? Is it finally taking off or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, three D printing. Got it. So what's the big deal? Is it finally taking off or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, well, actually, quite the opposite, in some ways. PitchBook reported that the 3D printing sector, as a whole, is really seeing a downturn in venture funding this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, well, actually, quite the opposite, in some ways. PitchBook reported that the three D printing sector, as a whole, is really seeing a downturn in venture funding this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis. If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? That's surprising. I thought it was, like, the next big thing. How bad is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? That's surprising. I thought it was, like, the next big thing. How bad is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, they've only attracted about $400 million this year so far. Compare that to, like, $800 million last year, or even a whopping $100 million in 2014, which was considered huge back then. It's a pretty significant drop.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, they've only attracted about four hundred million dollars this year so far. Compare that to, like, eight hundred million dollars last year, or even a whopping one hundred million dollars in twenty fourteen, which was considered huge back then. It's a pretty significant drop.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year... If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's, that's almost half. So where does "foot bones printing" come in? What's the interesting part?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's, that's almost half. So where does foot bones printing come in? What's the interesting part?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so *despite* this overall slump, there's one company, Carbon – they're a 3D printing company – that's about to rake in a massive $300 million investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so despite this overall slump, there's one company, Carbon - they're a three D printing company - that's about to rake in a massive three hundred million dollar investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, $300 million? That's huge! [interrupts] Is that enough to, like, turn the tide for the whole industry?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, three hundred million dollars? That's huge! Is that enough to, like, turn the tide for the whole industry?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, surprisingly, no. Even with that big Carbon deal, the sector still won't hit the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years. It just shows how big the drop has been.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, surprisingly, no. Even with that big Carbon deal, the sector still won't hit the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years. It just shows how big the drop has been.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Gosh, that really puts it in perspective. So what makes Carbon so special, then, if the whole industry is struggling and, you know, losing traction in the industrial space?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gosh, that really puts it in perspective. So what makes Carbon so special, then, if the whole industry is struggling and, you know, losing traction in the industrial space?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they're pretty well-known for their partnership with Adidas, actually. They're making the midsoles for their Futurecraft 4D running shoes. That's a pretty high-profile use case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they're pretty well-known for their partnership with Adidas, actually. They're making the midsoles for their Futurecraft four D running shoes. That's a pretty high-profile use case.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's right! I remember hearing about those shoes. So it's like, one standout company in an otherwise, um, challenging sector.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's right! I remember hearing about those shoes. So it's like, one standout company in an otherwise, um, challenging sector.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years... they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they've got some serious backers, too – like Sequoia, GV, Adidas Ventures. They're valued at, like, $1.7 billion, potentially $2.5 billion post-funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they've got some serious backers, too - like Sequoia, G V, Adidas Ventures. They're valued at, like, one point seven billion dollars, potentially two point five billion dollars post-funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Redwood City, California-based company counts Sequoia, GV, Fidelity, General Electric and Adidas Ventures among its existing investors. ... The company is currently valued at $1.7 billion, and could be worth as much as $2.5 billion after the new funding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a shining star, but not enough to pull up the whole ship, then. It's interesting how a few big deals, like Desktop Metal's or Markforged's, can still happen even in a down market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a shining star, but not enough to pull up the whole ship, then. It's interesting how a few big deals, like Desktop Metal's or Markforged's, can still happen even in a down market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's a really mixed bag for 3D printing right now. Big money for a select few, but a tougher road for the sector overall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's a really mixed bag for three D printing right now. Big money for a select few, but a tougher road for the sector overall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups. If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years...
